title: How to Make Snacks with Almond Butter

methods.name: Pairing Almond Butter With Fruit and Veggies

steps.headline: Go simple.
steps.description: One very simple snack is just fruit dipped into almond butter. For instance, try coring an apple and then cutting it into slices. Dip the slices into a small cup of almond butter, and enjoy. You can also try grapes, pears, or carrots.

steps.headline: Try almond butter and banana granola on the go.
steps.description: Peel a banana, cutting off any bad parts. Cut the banana down the center, length-wise. Spread the center of each half with almond butter. Dip the halves into granola so that it sticks to the almond butter.

steps.headline: Make a fruit spread.
steps.description: In a bowl, add as much cream cheese as you'd like. The cream cheese will be half the bulk of your dip. Make sure it's softened enough to mix or beat. Add the same amount of almond butter in, as well as a dash or two of cinnamon. Mix it well, using a mixer or a whisk. This dip tastes great with fruits like green apple slices, grapes, and even vegetables like celery.

steps.headline: Try ants on a log.
steps.description: This snack will take you back to your childhood, except instead of peanut butter, you'll use almond butter. Wash celery, and cut it in pieces that are about 4- to 5-inches long. Spread almond butter on the inside of the celery. Dot the almond butter with raisins, and chow down.

steps.headline: Make almond butter snack balls.
steps.description: Add a 1/4 cup of raw almonds to a food processor. Blend until they are ground up, but not fine enough to be flour. Add in 1/2 cup of almond butter, 2 cups of dates, 1 teaspoon of cinnamon, 1 teaspoon of vanilla, and 1/4 teaspoon of salt. Blend the ingredients together. Roll the mixture into ball. Place them in an airtight container. Keep these snacks in the fridge. They should last for 2 to 3 weeks.

steps.headline: Make a chocolate and almond butter toast.
steps.description: Choose whatever kind of bread you prefer. A grainy bread is a good choice. Toast a slice lightly, then spread it with almond butter. Sprinkle chopped chocolate or mini chocolate chips on top. Stick it back in the toaster or oven under the broiler for a few minutes until the chocolate just begins to melt. Use a knife to smooth out the melted chocolate into the almond butter. Make sure you don't cook the bread too long, as the chocolate can easily go past melting to burning.

steps.headline: Try banana and almond butter toast.
steps.description: Toast the bread of your choice. Try rye bread or a whole-grain bread. Spread a layer of almond butter on top, then add slices of bananas on top of that. This snack pairs slow-burning carbohydrates with protein, a good combination. You can also try sliced peaches on top.

steps.headline: Create spicy almond butter rice cakes.
steps.description: Use two plain (or whatever flavor) rice cakes. Spread almond butter on top of them. Next, drizzle on some sriracha. Make sure to not add too much if you're new to sriracha: it can get very spicy very quickly!

steps.headline: Try it in oatmeal.
steps.description: Another easy snack with almond butter is to add it to your oatmeal or other hot cereal. Cook your cereal like you normally would, then stir in some almond butter at the end. You can also add a drizzle of honey.

steps.headline: Make almond butter coconut milk.
steps.description: Add half a can of coconut milk to a blender, as well as 1/2 a teaspoon of cardamom and 3 tablespoons of almond butter. Blend it together well, adding honey or maple syrup to taste, if you want. For a colder beverage, throw in a ice cube or two when blending. If cardamom isn't your thing, try cinnamon, ginger, or nutmeg to taste.

steps.headline: Throw it in a smoothie.
steps.description: Almond butter makes a great addition to a smoothie. It adds protein, as well as provides thickness to the smoothie. Try adding it in after you've blended your fruits and veggies with a liquid and blend until smooth.

steps.headline: Create a decadent hot chocolate.
steps.description: Mix together a 1/2 cup of whole milk and a 1/4 cup of cream in a small saucepan. Heat it over medium heat for 4 to 5 minutes, until it's hot. It should be simmering, not boiling. Add in 5 ounces of chocolate (chopped or mini chocolate chips). Stir until the chocolate has melted, then add in a tablespoon of almond butter. Whisk again until smooth. You can use lower-fat milk, but the end result won't be as thick and creamy.

steps.headline: Gather your ingredients.
steps.description: You'll need whole roasted almonds, salt, and honey to taste to make almond butter. Add about 1/2 teaspoon of salt for every 1 1/2 cups of almonds you use. Start with 1 1/2 to 2 tablespoons of honey, though you may want a bit more, depending on your taste preferences. Roasted almonds make for a more flavorful spread. If you have raw almonds, you can toast them on an unlined baking sheet for 12 to 15 minutes at 325 degrees Fahrenheit (163 degrees Celsius).

steps.headline: Blend the almonds and the salt.
steps.description: Use a food processor to blend the almonds and the salt together. You may need to pulse it a few times at first. Keep blending the almonds and salt together until they form a relatively smooth paste. If it's not smooth enough for your tastes, you can add a bit of a neutral oil, such as grapeseed oil, to help smooth things out.

steps.headline: Add the honey.
steps.description: Next, pour the honey into the food processor. Blend the mixture again until the honey is fully mixed in. Taste the almond butter to see if it needs more salt or honey. Adjust as needed, and blend again. Place in an airtight jar, and use as you would any almond butter. Another good addition at this point is a dash or two of cinnamon, which brings warmth to your almond butter.
